p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: -0.8862in; margin-right: 0in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: 0.0417in; text-align: end; text-indent: 0.8862in; color: #0000ff;

div.p: Firm dating depends on sorting out the sequence of letters, dated and undated to Williamson, but it is likely to be 1893, possibly December, or early 1894, depending on the datings of the letters mentioned in the attribution fn. I have highlighted letters still not secure in their dating in fns

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: -0.8862in; margin-right: 0in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: 0.0417in; text-align: end; text-indent: 0.8862in; color: #0000ff;

div.p: Williamson as HT of State School Upper Castle Creek in May 1890 when Kilmore Hospital received money collected by pupils at the school )Euro Advertiser, 23 May 1890, p. 2)

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: -0.8862in; margin-right: 0in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: 0.0417in; text-align: end; text-indent: 0.8862in; color: #0000ff;

div.p: Williamson apppointed to Tylden State School May 1891 (Argus 9 May 1891, p. 5);

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: -0.8862in; margin-right: 0in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: 0.0417in; text-align: end; text-indent: 0.8862in; color: #0000ff;

div.p: at Hawkesdale State School, in March 1894, (Ovens and Murray Valley Advertiser, 10 March 94, p. 11;

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: -0.8862in; margin-right: 0in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: 0.0417in; text-align: end; text-indent: 0.8862in; color: #0000ff;

div.p: Still at Hawkesdale March 1889, when daughter born in Warrnambool (Argus 13 March 99, p. 1)

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;
p.seg: The recipient is inferred to be Herbert Williamson, based on the contents of related letters known to be to him: M to H. Williamson, 19 December 1893 (in this edition as 93-12-19a) and another, undated, letter in this edition as
, as it is a letter in response to Williamson's response (letter not found) to M's request in M to H. Williamson,
for information about the bee flora

cell.p: Leptorrhynchos tenuifolius F.v.M. Like ripe seeds of this

cell.style: padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

div.p:
Best thanks for the interesting information on the Mt Sturgeon
Vic. honey-station. I suppose you are quite sure about the names of all your Eucalypts, (I say Eucalypt s like we say Oaks, Elms &c.) The flowering time for length &c, depends on locality and clime locally, varied rainfalls in the season also.
Best thanks for the additional seaweeds.

The Mylittas
The fungus Laccocephalum mylittae ('Blackfellow's bread'), formerly known as Mylitta australis or Polyporus mylittae. will be quite a boon, as frequent demands for them arise from abroad and this helps me in my foreign interchanges. They always dry on their own accord. If put into a corn or potato-bag, and put on the railway, I should get them all right and I will [re]fund the freight or pay it here. Indeed I shall be very thankful for them. Hedypnois and Nepeta are immigrated. The allien plants, settling here, increase from year to year. The Pomaderris shall be carefully examined.

Please ask your kind brother to look for Aldrovanda
A fragment in M's hand held in the same archives, reads
'Aldrovanda vesiculosa L.', followed by a sketch: Chiltern00-00-00_image01.jpg
The note continues 'For Australia as yet only shown in two lagoons of S. Queensland. Leaves transparent, [ketching] water-animalculs. Flo[wers] white, but [barely] dev[…]'. in the lagoons near him. It may even occur in waters of the region, in which you dwell.
Herbert Williamson's brother Arthur John Williamson lived in Chiltern, Vic, and is recorded as collecting specimens for MEL. Herbert was teaching at Hawkesdale, midway between Port Fairy and Mt Sturgeon, in 1894 when he was thanked for 'his valuable donation of a piece of "Mylittas Australia" to the museum' of the Chiltern Athenaeum (Ovens and Murray advertiser, 10 March 1894, p. 11).
